#Text=Boston/North End
#Text=Known as " Little Italy " for over a hundred years , the North End proudly carries the torch of Boston 's Italian heritage .
#Text=Its narrow , dense streets consistently draw hordes of visitors looking to experience old world culture and first class dining .
#Text=The West End was a sister neighborhood , until it was almost entirely demolished during the 1950s .
#Text=Today it 's the site of a huge sports arena and massive amounts of new construction .
#Text=North End
#Text=The draw of the North End was evident even to the first Puritan colonists , when powerful minister Increase Mather made this neighborhood his home .
#Text=This area shared fortunes with Beacon Hill , and people from all walks of life came together to live and worship .
#Text=The Old North Church was put up in 1723 , the oldest church in Boston still standing .
#Text=As the years wore on , the English and free Blacks living here would be pushed out by a wave of Irish immigrants who arrived in great numbers .
#Text=Stately mansions were converted into tenements , and living conditions deteriorated .
#Text=By the mid 19th century , the North End developed something of an unsavory reputation , a red-light district along what is today North Street being chiefly responsible .
#Text=By the 1880s the Irish had decamped , and the North End became dominated by Jewish and especially Italian immigrants .
#Text=These families would barter trade skills to one another , slowly repairing and replacing the area 's dilapidated housing stock with what you will see here today .
#Text=A poorly considered expressway project constructed in 1950s cut this neighborhood off from the rest of Boston .
#Text=Although this did have the beneficial effect of strengthening already close community connections , and family owned businesses continued to thrive .

#Text=When the ugly expressway was removed in 2007 by the Big Dig , a hulking metal barrier was replaced by a welcoming green garden , and the North End was united with the rest of the city once more .

#Text=This connective parkland invites visitors from around the globe to explore the narrow brick streets , historical highlights , and unparalleled Italian dining that make the North End such a unique destination .
#Text=West End
#Text=Once simply a small bay and mill pond to early colonists , the West End is another of Boston 's neighborhoods built on reclaimed land .
#Text=After the American revolution , the pond had turned into something of a convenient — although increasingly stinky — garbage dump .
#Text=By the dawn of the 19th century it was decided to use the earth from one of Beacon Hill 's three original hills to fill the pond in .
#Text=The creation of this new neighborhood quickly relieved pressure on the town 's overcrowded housing stock .
#Text=Some of the areas first residents would be African American , joining friends and family living nearby on Beacon Hill 's north slope .
#Text=This was one of the few places in the United States where African Americans had a political voice before the Civil War .
#Text=In the coming years they would be joined by immigrants arriving from across Europe , Russia , and the Middle East .
#Text=By the 1950s the once overcrowded area was in the process of " de-slumming " along with the North End .
#Text=It was n't perfect , but small shops were still in business and many families still considered it a fine place to live .
#Text=A city plan to " redevelop " the area was overwhelmingly opposed by residents during a meeting in late 1957 .
#Text=Their pleas fell on deaf ears , however , and eviction notices were handed out a few months later .
#Text=The following year , a majority of the West End would be razed to the ground .
#Text=Today a vibrancy is slowly returning to the remaining pockets of what once was .

#Text=It will never again feel like a sister to the North End , but as the tall buildings of glass and steel take the place of 50s era parking lots , the West End stands ready to turn the page and write its next chapter .
#Text=By foot
#Text=The North and West End are of similar size and can be traversed in around 15-20 minutes , so walking is usually going to be your best option .
#Text=The easiest way to get to the North End is to follow the Freedom Trail from downtown Boston ; follow the crowd across the Greenway and you 're there .
#Text=For the West End , turn left as the Greenway ends and the Charlestown bridge looms .
#Text=By public transit
#Text=By far the largest station in the area is North Station .
#Text=Not only is this a major stop on the Orange and Green lines , four Commuter Rail lines and the Amtrak train to Maine depart from here as well .
#Text=See Boston by train for more information .
#Text=While covered more in depth in the downtown article , Haymarket on the Orange and Green lines can be a very useful station for the visitor .
#Text=Accessible by Green line tracks ;
#Text=Science Park is the station you want if you 're visiting the Science Museum .
#Text=If you 're going to be on the Blue line anyway , Aquarium or Bowdoin stations may also prove useful to you .
#Text=By car
#Text=Here are two more neighborhoods where driving is a terrible idea .
#Text=The North End in particular has streets so narrow they barely accommodate pedestrians , much less automobiles .
#Text=When visitors are n't clogging up the thoroughfares in summer , the snow picks up that slack in wintertime .
#Text=There are a few ( expensive ) parking garages in the West End and downtown if you 're determined to go that route .
#Text=A few businesses in this area may provide valet parking , but call ahead to ensure a spot and do n't expect it to come gratis .
#Text=See
#Text=Old North Church ( Christ Church in the City of Boston ) , 193 Salem St ( T : North Station ) , ☏ +1617 523-6676 .
#Text=Jan-Feb : 10AM-4PM daily , Mar-May : 9AM-5PM daily , Jun-Oct : 9AM-6PM daily , Nov-Dec : 9AM-5PM daily .
#Text=Old North Church was Boston ’s second Anglican church .
#Text=It is most famous for sending the message from Paul Revere that the British were coming by lighting the steeple with lanterns .
#Text=" One if by land , two if by sea .
